Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Student Travel Grants for IEEE Wireless Communications and Networking Conference 2017

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The IEEE Wireless Communications and Networking Conference (WCNC) is a major conference of the IEEE Communications Society. It has been held continuously since 1999. It covers a broad range of topics in wireless communications and networking including advanced cellular systems, device-to-device communication, multi-antenna communication schemes, channel modeling, interference management, and wireless energy transfer. The conference brings together industry, academia, and government and regulatory bodies. The technical program for WCNC 2017 will feature numerous technical sessions including physical layer fundamentals, medium access control, cross-layer design, wireless networks, emerging technologies, architectures, and services, as well as tutorials, workshops, and technology/business panels.

WCNC 2017 will be hosted by the city of San Francisco and Silicon Valley from March 19th to 22nd. Historically, the conference has had approximately 10% student participation. A goal of the organizing committee this year is to increase student participation to 15%. To do this, the organizing committee created two Student Outreach Chairs positions and has planned four specific student outreach activities. This grant provides travel assistance to approximately 50 deserving US-based students to allow for increased student participation and engagement at WCNC 2017. The Student Outreach chairs will support applications from a diverse mix of students and will make efforts to draw applications from female students and students from underrepresented minorities. After the 2017 WCNC event is complete, the Student Outreach Chairs will email student attendees a short online survey to assess the effectiveness of the outreach events as well as the travel grant application and award process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The travel grant was used to support domestic-based student 26 attendees to the IEEE Wireless Communications and Network Conference (WCNC) in March 19-22, 2017. More details regarding student travel grant applicants and their support are provided below:

  • 2 of the 26 domestic student travel grant attendees were female.
  • A total of 27 students were awarded the travel grants but one student could not attend in the end and did not use his funds.
  • A total of 81 students applied for travel grants;  27 were domestic and 54 international.
  • Given the NSF support, each domestic applicant was approved for funding and received a total of $740.74.
  • 9 international students were supported using $7500 of funds contributed by IEEE Communications Society.
  • In addition, IEEE Communication Society Women in Communication Engineering provided $1000 to support two international female students.  

The student attendees were encouraged to attend a number of program events specificially designed for them. These are outlined below:

  • Student Mentorship Event:  This was a highly successful event whose goal was to enable to students to forge future connections as well receive career development guidance from senior leaders.  During this session, there were approximately five concurrent table discussions centered around themes of interest to students, e.g., “How to Get an Academic Job,” “Industry versus Academia,” “Do’s and Don’ts of Interviewing,” etc.  Students had the opportunity to rotate every half hour to participate in multiple discussions. Postdocs are also welcome. This session is hosted by the NSF Center for Science of Information.  The designated room for this event was packed with students and the overall event was enthusiastically well-received.
  • Student Poster and Demo Session: This was a session dedicated towards student posters, demonstrations and prototypes. A panel of distinguished judges selected the Best Student Poster and Best Student Demonstration. These awards were presented by a representative of the Marconi Society Young Scholar Program. The Marconi Society generously sponsored this session and its awards.  The list of demos and posters can be found here: http://wcnc2017.ieee-wcnc.org/content/student-program.
  • Student-Industry Recruiting Event: This event enabled students to discuss their job interests with industry and startup exhibitors. Students could bring their questions and resumes to the exhibit booths of the companies they are interested in. Postdocs were also welcome. 
  • Student-Industry Networking Session: All student and industry attendees were invited to this informal mixer to meet friends and make new contacts. Postdocs were also welcome.

In addtion, to the activities noted above and the technical program, student attendees (including NSF travel grant recepients) were encouraged to participate as student volunteers.
